tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content: 20:00 S: Patient John Doe, 55 years old, admitted for alcohol withdrawal. B: History of chronic alcohol abuse. Last drink was approximately 12 hours ago. Currently exhibiting signs of withdrawal. A: Patient is increasingly agitated and confused. Vital signs: BP 140/90 mmHg, HR 110 bpm, Temp 99.5°F. Patient reports feeling anxious and tremulous. Administered lorazepam 2mg IV per protocol at 19:30. R: Requesting orders for further management of alcohol withdrawal, including potential need for increased sedation and monitoring for delirium tremens. Continuous vital sign monitoring recommended.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content: General: Appears agitated and diaphoretic. Neuro: Disoriented to place and time. Tremors noted in hands. Reports visual hallucinations. Cardiovascular: Tachycardic. Respiratory: Breathing rapidly. Skin: Diaphoretic.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
• Monitor vital signs every hour.
  • Administer lorazepam 2mg IV PRN for agitation.
  • Initiate fall precautions.
  • Monitor for signs of delirium tremens.
  • Provide a quiet and safe environment.

rationale.correct: Hypotension (BP 90/60 mmHg), tachycardia (HR 120 bpm), and elevated temperature (102.5°F or 39.2°C) are signs of severe alcohol withdrawal and potential delirium tremens, requiring immediate medical intervention. Visual hallucinations are also a critical symptom indicating delirium. These findings suggest the patient's condition is deteriorating and needs immediate attention.
rationale.incorrect: Agitation and disorientation, while concerning, are expected findings in alcohol withdrawal. However, they do not represent the same level of immediate threat as unstable vital signs or hallucinations. These symptoms should be addressed, but the vital signs and hallucinations take priority.

answerBreakdown.label: agitation
answerBreakdown.content: Agitation is a common symptom of alcohol withdrawal but is not the highest priority for immediate notification unless accompanied by other critical findings.

answerBreakdown.label: disorientation to place and time
answerBreakdown.content: Disorientation is expected during alcohol withdrawal; however, it is not as critical as unstable vital signs or hallucinations and does not require immediate notification on its own.

answerBreakdown.label: BP 90/60 mmHg
answerBreakdown.content: Hypotension in the context of alcohol withdrawal can indicate hypovolemia, sepsis, or cardiovascular compromise, all of which require immediate medical intervention.

answerBreakdown.label: HR 120 bpm
answerBreakdown.content: Tachycardia in alcohol withdrawal can be a sign of autonomic instability and potential progression to delirium tremens, requiring immediate assessment and intervention.

answerBreakdown.label: temperature 102.5°F (39.2°C)
answerBreakdown.content: Elevated temperature during alcohol withdrawal could indicate infection or delirium tremens, necessitating immediate evaluation and treatment.

answerBreakdown.label: visual hallucinations of spiders crawling on the walls
answerBreakdown.content: Visual hallucinations are a classic symptom of delirium tremens and require immediate medical intervention to prevent further complications.

clinicalPearls: Alcohol withdrawal can rapidly progress to a life-threatening condition. Close monitoring of vital signs and mental status is crucial.
Delirium tremens typically presents with altered mental status, hallucinations, and autonomic instability (tachycardia, hypertension, fever).

questionTrap.trap: Focusing solely on the behavioral symptoms (agitation, disorientation) without recognizing the physiological instability (vital signs) can lead to delayed intervention.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize assessment of vital signs and physiological parameters when evaluating a patient with alcohol withdrawal. Changes in vital signs often precede or accompany changes in mental status.
